channel.title: Download ubuntu?
channel.description: ok so im running xp and everyone is saying that ohhh download ubuntu, im curious to install it but wondering how it would work? would it remove my windows xp software and install all there stuff? will it remove all the files i have? anything else i should know about please tell me. thanks everyone. i hope ubunutu works, but i wanna here a lil more about it.

item.title: Download ubuntu?
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

Dual boots bbz.
Windows has good points but so does Ubuntu.
Get it and also keep Windows.
Order of awesomesauceness Win 7>Ubuntu(I game a lot which Ubuntu can sometimes have troubles with as not everything is supported that Windows is)>Win xp.
Rest = junk0rz (:

Read full topic

item.title: Download ubuntu?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“ziplock, post:11, topic:415991”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=517936.msg3763341#msg3763341 date=1317044349]

I was curious too.

Download the installer and put it onto an empty disk (blank CD/DVD) then install it on startup.
You can either keep windows and add ubuntu, or remove windows completely and install ubuntu. You will lose all of your windows files unless backed up on a flash drive or something like that. You also might want to have access to a wired connection, because sometimes you need to install missing network drivers (happened to me twice, pain in the ass).

oh well ima not risk it. ill just get windows 7 and get a new desktop. i dont like laptops anymore, not enoough space.

Space as in hard drive space? Buy a new hard drive, can get 640gb hdds for under £50 these days (or like $90, not sure).
It’s as easy as changing a battery.
[/quote]

Nahh. You can get a 1TB for around $65[/quote]
Not 2.5" laptop hdd’s, 3.5"s yes.

Read full topic

You can either keep windows and add ubuntu, or remove windows completely and install ubuntu. You will lose all of your windows files unless backed up on a flash drive or something like that. You also might want to have access to a wired connection, because sometimes you need to install missing network drivers (happened to me twice, pain in the ass).

oh well ima not risk it. ill just get windows 7 and get a new desktop. i dont like laptops anymore, not enoough space.
[/quote]
Space as in hard drive space? Buy a new hard drive, can get 640gb hdds for under £50 these days (or like $90, not sure).
It’s as easy as changing a battery.[/quote]

Nahh. You can get a 1TB for around $65

item.title: Download ubuntu?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“xmonster, post:3, topic:415991”][quote author=Fridder link=topic=517936.msg3762929#msg3762929 date=1316998026]
I was curious too.

Download the installer and put it onto an empty disk (blank CD/DVD) then install it on startup.
You can either keep windows and add ubuntu, or remove windows completely and install ubuntu. You will lose all of your windows files unless backed up on a flash drive or something like that. You also might want to have access to a wired connection, because sometimes you need to install missing network drivers (happened to me twice, pain in the ass).
[/quote]
oh well ima not risk it. ill just get windows 7 and get a new desktop. i dont like laptops anymore, not enoough space.[/quote]
Space as in hard drive space? Buy a new hard drive, can get 640gb hdds for under £50 these days (or like $90, not sure).
It’s as easy as changing a battery.

item.title: Download ubuntu?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“xryz, post:7, topic:415991”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=517936.msg3763215#msg3763215 date=1317015845]
You can use the Ubuntu LiveCD to test out any and all features of a fresh installation of Ubuntu, without installing it. If, at some point, you decide that you would like to install it alongside, or even over the current windows installation, there is an installation wizard to help you through that process on the LiveCD.
[/quote]

he could also use wubi which would probably be the simplest for him, since u install/uninstall it just like a windows program.[/quote]

The LiveCD allows him to install it immediately after testing. Otherwise it would look something like

Start computer Boot LiveCD Test features Decide to install Restart machine Boot windows Run wubi Finish installation Restart computer Boot Ubuntu

Instead of

Start computer Boot LiveCD Test features Decide to install Run Installer Finish installation Restart computer Boot Ubuntu

Read full topic

item.title: Download ubuntu?
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

zyle1992:

You can use the Ubuntu LiveCD to test out any and all features of a fresh installation of Ubuntu, without installing it. If, at some point, you decide that you would like to install it alongside, or even over the current windows installation, there is an installation wizard to help you through that process on the LiveCD.

he could also use wubi which would probably be the simplest for him, since u install/uninstall it just like a windows program.

Read full topic

item.title: Download ubuntu?
item.dc:creator: @Ix_Soulcist_xI Soulcist
item.description:
@Ix_Soulcist_xI wrote:

[quote=“ziplock, post:4, topic:415991”][quote author=xmonster link=topic=517936.msg3763014#msg3763014 date=1317000804]

I was curious too.

Download the installer and put it onto an empty disk (blank CD/DVD) then install it on startup.
You can either keep windows and add ubuntu, or remove windows completely and install ubuntu. You will lose all of your windows files unless backed up on a flash drive or something like that. You also might want to have access to a wired connection, because sometimes you need to install missing network drivers (happened to me twice, pain in the ass).

oh well ima not risk it. ill just get windows 7 and get a new desktop. i dont like laptops anymore, not enoough space.
[/quote]

Risk what? By getting Widows 7, you’re risking about $200 you could save. It’s not like running Linux takes a degree in Computer Science. Although people tend to think of it as some black magic for some reason.[/quote]
Why should someone pay for the software when they can give it for free?

Read full topic
